newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish coalition partners begin polls meeting.
newsitem.headline: Turkish coalition partners begin polls meeting.

text.p: Turkish Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan began a meeting with his coalition partner Tansu Ciller on Friday in bargaining about possible early elections to solve a government crisis over Islamist activism.
The talks, at Erbakan's official residence, started an hour later than planned but the reason for the delay was not immediately clear.
Foreign Minister Ciller said on Thursday she would press Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, to make her prime minister in a caretaker government that would take the country to the polls.
Elections would normally be due by the year 2000.

The 11-month-old alliance between Erbakan and pro-Western Ciller has been crumbling under pressure from the secularist establishment, which sees Erbakan's Welfare Party as the source of an Islamist revival in officially secular Turkey.
An MP announced his resignation from Ciller's conservative True Path Party on Friday, robbing the government of its absolute majority in parliament.
The resignation reduces the number of government MPs to 275, one short of the absolute majority needed to win any vote of confidence at the 550-member assembly.

Erbakan and Ciller are set to swap jobs next year under a power-sharing deal that established their alliance last June. But Ciller says she can ward off anti-Islamist pressure on the government from the army if she takes the top job sooner.
The Turkish press said on Friday that Erbakan had agreed to hand over power to Ciller but that the pair disagreed on when new elections should take place.
The Hurriyet daily said Erbakan, whose party is facing closure in an anti-Islamist crackdown, wants to go to the nation in October while Ciller favours next March.
